Graphical abstract Polar-rich-group triazine-based covalent organic frameworks (COF-TzDha) with de-solvation effects as an interlayer are designed. The Li-Li symmetric cell with COF-TzDha modified separators cycles stably without any dendrites in lithium-metal anode. The uneven deposition and high reactivity of lithium-metal anode (LMA) lead to uncontrollable dendrite growth, low Coulombic efficiency, and safety concerns, hindering their commercialization. Here, a representative polar-rich-group triazine-based covalent organic framework (COF-TzDha) with a desolvation effect is designed as an interlayer for stable, dendrite-free LMA. The abundant triazine rings in COF-TzDha as a donor effectively attract lithium ions, while the one-dimensional nanopore structure facilitates lithium-ion migration. The periodic arrangement of polar groups (–OH) in the backbone interacts with electrolyte components (DOL, DME, TFSI−) to form a hydrogen bonding network that slows solvent molecules transport. Therefore, COF-TzDha effectively desolvates lithium ions from the solvent sheath, promoting uniform lithium ion flux and Li plating/stripping. Theoretical calculations verify that COF-TzDha with abundant adsorption sites and strong adsorption energy facilitates lithium ion de-solvation. Consequently, the introduction of COF-TzDha obtains a high ion mobility (0.75). The Li|COF@PP|Li symmetric cell cycles stably for over 1200 h at 4 mA cm−2/4.0 mA h cm−2. The Li|COF@PP|LiFePO4 full cell also displays highly stable cycling performance with 600 cycles (75.5% capacity retention, ∼100% Coulombic efficiency) at 1 C. This work verifies an effective strategy for inducing uniform Li deposition and achieving dendrite-free, stable LMA using a polar-rich-group COF interlayer with a desolvation effect. Keywords Covalent organic frameworks Modified separators De-solvation effect Lithium dendrites Lithium metal batteries 1 Introduction Since the commercial introduction of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) in the 1990s, there has been unprecedented development in electronic information technology and new energy storage devices. Graphite has been the favored anode material for commercial LIBs (with a capacity of 372 mA h g−1) [1]. However, with decades of progress, higher demands for energy device density have emerged, and the energy density of LIBs using graphite as the anode is approaching its theoretical limit. Lithium-metal batteries (LMBs) are considered ideal candidates for the next generation of high-performance energy storage devices due to their high theoretical capacity (3860 mA h g−1) and very low reduction potential (−3.04 V vs. SHE) [2]. Nevertheless, the high reactivity of lithium metal makes it difficult to establish a stable and homogeneous solid electrolyte interface in LMBs, resulting in local aggregation of ions and electrons, allowing for side reactions to occur [3]. As cycling progresses, continuous consumption of lithium metal and electrolyte leads to uncontrollable lithium dendrite growth, ultimately generating “dead lithium”, reducing Coulombic efficiency (CE), posing substantial safety issues, significantly hampering practical applications [4–7]. To address the above problems, researchers have proposed various new strategies to develop dendrite-free deposition and inhibit dendrite growth of lithium metal, such as electrolyte design [8–10], interface engineering [11–13], and lithium host structure modification [14–18]. Electrolyte design is primarily utilized to stabilize the lithium-metal anode interface by optimizing the electrolyte, adding additives, and regulating electrolyte components, concentration and molecular structure. Interfacial engineering refers to the construction of a high mechanical modulus, stable and homogeneous, ion-conducting and electrically insulating SEI to protect the lithium metal anode (LMA) by in-situ/ex-situ methods [19,20]. Lithium host structure modification involves the employment of a multi-dimensional conductive skeleton to change the local current density, thus lengthening the Sand's Time to achieve the effect of suppressing dendrites [21]. Unfortunately, although the aforementioned techniques have produced some results, commercialization of LMBs is still a ways off [22–25]. Recently, the research on the modification of separator to inhibit lithium dendrites has attracted great attention [26]. The modified separator is not only able to precisely regulate the lithium ion flux, but also improve the lithium ion mobility. This scheme greatly simplifies the preparation process by eliminating the need to add expensive additives to the electrolyte and tedious construction of a protective layer on the lithium metal surface [27–32]. Therefore, it becomes crucial to find a functional material that can regulate the Li+ flux and optimize the ion transport [33–38]. Covalent organic skeletons (COFs), as a novel type of material with abundant ordered pores, high specific surface area, tunable structure, and designable function, have been widely applied in various fields such as adsorption [39,40], gas storage [41], catalysis [42,43], and so on. In recent years, the application of stable and porous COFs as separators in LMBs has received much attention [44–48]. However, the separator modified with COF also has some drawbacks. Firstly, some COFs with poor electrochemical activity have a weak ability to interact with lithium ions, which makes it difficult to guide the ions to be transported uniformly. Second, larger solvent sheath molecules can easily accumulate in the COF layer, resulting in a lower ion mobility. Therefore, designing a unique functional group COF as an interlayer to desolvate the lithium ions in the solvent sheath of electrolyte and induce uniform deposition of lithium ions is extremely critical but highly challenging for achieving a stable, dendrite-free lithium-metal anode. Here, we design a lithium-friendly triazinyl COF (TzDha) with polar-rich groups (–OH) and a desolvation effect as a multifunctional inter-layer to induce uniform Li ion flux and deposition for dendrite-free, stable LMBs (Scheme 1 a). Thanks to the layered porous structure of COF-TzDha, the electrolyte can fully wet the modified separator and improve the dynamic performance of the battery (Scheme 1b). Among them, the abundant triazine ring on COF-TzDha can attract lithium ions, while the one-dimensional orderly nanopore structure can promote the migration of lithium ions, and the periodically arranged polar groups on the backbone can also interact with the electrolyte to obtain a higher concentration of electrolyte. Specifically, when lithium ions pass through the separator from the cathode to the anode, the abundant hydroxyl functional groups on COF-TzDha will form a hydrogen bonding network with DME, DOL, and TFSI− in the electrolyte, which results in the desolvation of lithium ions and the enhancement of lithium ion mobility, thus significantly increasing the exchange current density (I 0) and decreasing the activation energy (E 0) of Li-Li symmetric cells, as confirmed by kinetic and thermodynamic experiments ( Scheme 1c). Density functional theory (DFT) calculations confirm the presence of abundant active sites on each constituent unit of COF-TzDha. These active sites exhibit higher binding energies with lithium ions compared to DOL and DME solvent molecules, resulting in the intermediate layer achieving a higher t Li + (0.75) and facilitating the desolvation of lithium ions. Molecular dynamics further suggests that COF-TzDha has a good lithium ion diffusion capacity and an anchoring anion (TFSI−). As expected, the Li|COF@PP|Li symmetric cells with COF-TzDha modified PP separator can cycle stably for over 1000 h with an ultra-low over-potential of 15 mV at 1.0 mA cm−2/1.0 mA h cm−2. Impressively, even at 4 mA cm−2/4.0 mA h cm−2, it also displays a 1200 h cycle stability. Such high stability is superior to these reported Li-Li symmetrical batteries with other COFs modified separators (Tables S3 and S4). Besides, the LiFePO4|COF@PP|Li full cell presents a highly stable cycling with 600 cycles (75.5 capacity retention, ∼100% CE) at 1 C, and its pouch cell can easily drive a 3 V handheld fan, verifying its promising practical applications. Therefore, this work verifies an effective strategy to induce the uniform Li deposition for dendrite-free LMA through using a polar-rich-group COF interlayer with a desolvation effect. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of COF-TzDha COF-TzDha was synthesised based on previously reported literature [49]. 4,4′,4′'-(1,3,5-Triazine-2,4,6-triyl)trianiline (Tz, 31.9 mg, 0.09 mmol), 2,5-Dihydroxyterephthalaldehyde (Dha, 21.6 mg, 0.13 mmol), o-dichlorobenzene (o-DCB, 1.8 mL), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc, 0.2 mL), and 6 M acetic acid (0.2 mL) were poured into a beaker and sonicated for 5 min, and then charged into Pyrex tubes, freeze–pump–thaw cycle degassed 3 times, then sealed with flame and heated at 120 °C for 72 h. The dark red product formed was collected by centrifugation, rinsed with tetrahydrofuran (THF) and dichloromethane (DCM), respectively, and then dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 12 h to obtain COF-TzDha in about 86% yield. 2.2 Fabrication of COF-TzDha@PP COF-TzDha and PVDF powder were mixed, then added to an NMP solution and sonicated for 30 min to form a homogeneous dispersion. The suspension was deposited onto one side of the PP separator via vacuum filtration, followed by drying under vacuum at 60 °C for 12 h. Finally, the COF-TzDha@PP separators were cut into 19 mm diameter circular disks. 2.3 Electrochemical characterization Half/full cell (CR2025) assemblies for electrochemical measurements were performed in a glove box (argon atmosphere, H2O < 0.01, O2 < 0.01). For lithium-copper cells, a LAND CT2001 battery system was used to discharge the cells cross-currently at 1 mA cm−2 for one hour, followed by a Galvanostatic charge up to 1.0 V to stop. For symmetric cells, two identical lithium foils were used as the working and counter electrodes, and the unmodified or COF-TzDha modified PP separator was used as the separators, denoted as Li| PP |Li and Li|COF@PP|Li, respectively. The electrolyte consisted of 1.0 M LiTFSI dissolved in a 1:1 vol ratio of 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) and 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME), with the addition of 2 wt% lithium nitrate. The amount of electrolyte for both half/full cells was 50 μL. 70 wt% LiFePO4 (LFP) powder, 20 wt% carbon black, and 10 wt% PVDF were mixed and poured into N-Methyl pyrrolidone solution to prepare a slurry to be coated on an Al foil, which was dried overnight in a vacuum oven at 60 °C. The LFP was loaded with a mass of 3.0 mg cm−2, a capacity of 0.51 mA h cm−2. The Li-LFP pouch cells were assembled with the following procedures: LFP as the cathode, 30 μm Li/Cu as the anode (China Energy Lithium Co., Ltd.), the electrode with the width of 5 cm, the length of 5 cm. Assembling the positive electrode, TzDha@PP separator, negative electrode, and separator in order, and the number of the stacked layers is 3. Before testing, the Li-LFP pouch cells were placed for 12 h. The test voltage window of the LFP-Li full cell was in the range of 2.4–3.8 V. Cyclic voltammetry curves were recorded at a scanning rate of 0.1 mV s−1. AC impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed on an electrochemical workstation (CHI 660e) with a frequency range of 0.01–100000 Hz and an AC amplitude of 10 mV. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and physical characterization of COF-TzDha Firstly, COF-TzDha was synthesized by a solvothermal method using 2,4,6-tris(4-aminophenyl)-1,3,5-triazine (Tz) and 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalaldehyde (Dha) (Scheme 1a). In this case, the reversible Schiff base reaction between the amines and aldehydes groups ensured that the covalently linked backbone had a planar structure, thus COF-TzDha with high crystallinity and stability, rich in hydroxyl groups, was formed. The structural characterization of COF-TzDha was carried out using X-ray diffraction (XRD), which exhibits good crystallinity with a strong diffraction peak at 2θ = 3.28°, attributed to the (100) plane. Signals near 5.22°, 5.94°, 7.84°, 10.14°, and 26.54° can be assigned to the (110), (200), (120), (220), and (001) planes, respectively (Fig. S1). Material Studio was used to model the COF-TzDha structure. Pawley refinement was undertaken in the P6/m space group (a = b = 36.2000 Å, c = 3.4000 Å). A comparison between the experimental data and the calculated PXRD curves, the AA stacking mode agrees well with the experimental PXRD data, as evidenced by the good agreement factors of R wp = 4.78% and R p = 3.42% (Fig. S2). This layered structure allows the polar OH groups to be vertically aligned next to each other, effectively achieving the dissociation of lithium ions. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) results show the disappearance of the NH2 peak of Tz (3210–3460 cm−1) and the CO peak of Dha (1670 cm−1), as well as the appearance of a stretching vibration band of COF-TzDha at 1618 cm−1 (CN), illustrating the precise synthesis of COF (Fig. 1 a). In addition, the signal at ∼160.29 ppm (Fig. 1b, peak 6) in the 13C NMR spectrum of COF-TzDha is attributable to the chemical shift of C=N, further validating the successful synthesis of the target COF. The permanent porosity of COF-TzDha was investigated by measuring the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area. The calculated specific surface area and pore size were found to be 614.64 m2 g−1 (Fig. 1c) and 2.29 nm (Fig. 1d), respectively. Furthermore, the thermal stability of COF-TzDha was revealed by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). As shown in Fig. S3, the thermal decomposition temperature of COF-TzDha under a nitrogen atmosphere was 400 °C, indicating that COF-TzDha has good thermal stability. The COF-TzDha powder was analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The presence of C, N, and O elements in COF-TzDha (Fig. S4a), and the C 1s spectra at 284.7, 286.1, 286.9, and 290.6 eV showed four peaks corresponding to the CC, CN, CN, and CO bonds, respectively (Fig. S4b). The N 1s spectrum indicated the presence of CN (398.9 eV) and CN (400 eV) components in the COF-TzDha structure (Fig. S4c). In O 1s, the peak at 532.8 eV can be attributed to the CO bond of COF-TzDha (Fig. S4d). In order to demonstrate the amphiphilicity of COF-TzDha, its interaction mechanism with the electrolyte was discussed. COF-TzDha was immersed in LiTFSI solution in a glove box, mixed and stirred for 6 h and then washed and dried. It was found by 7Li solid-state NMR that the LiTFSI signal shifted from −0.752 to −1.341 ppm after the addition of COF-TzDha, and the results indicated that the addition of COF-TzDha led to a change in the chemical environment of lithium ions in LiTFSI (Fig. 1e). This effect may be attributed to the groups on the COF, where the nitrogen atom in the triazine ring can act as an electron donor to attract lithium ions, while the abundant hydroxyl functional group will form a hydrogen bonding network with TFSI− and promote the dissociation of Li+. To further verify the affinity of COF-TzDha with Li ions, the mixed samples with LiTFSI were analysed for zeta potential and particle size, respectively. As shown in Table S1 and Fig. 1f, the average zeta potential of the COF-TzDha dispersion was −2.089, and the average zeta potential of the mixed sample after the addition of LiTFSI increased to −0.637, corresponding to an increase in the average particle size from 3810 to 7524 nm. This result proves that COF-TzDha achieves the desolvation effect of LiTFSI, and a large number of free lithium ions accumulate in the pro-lithium COF-TzDha nearby, forming a polymer with a larger particle size. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images of COF-TzDha exhibit a nano-bar morphology (Fig. 2 a, b). By EDS spectroscopy, it was observed that carbon, nitrogen and oxygen elements were uniformly distributed on COF-TzDha (Fig. 2c). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images also exhibit the morphology of nanostrips for COF-TzDha (Fig. 2d, e). A series of COF-TzDha@PP modified separators were obtained by vacuum filtration of the material at different loadings onto commercial PP separators. Although higher loadings can further enhance the physical barrier to lithium dendrites, high loadings result in a thicker separator, which increases the migration path for lithium ions, and consequently presents a greater barrier to ion migration. And lower loading capacity cannot sufficiently homogenise the lithium ions, weakening the inhibition of dendrites [50]. Therefore, we controlled the loading amount at 0.1 mg cm−2 and observed the cross-sectional image of the COF-TzDha@PP separator using SEM, and it can be seen that the thickness of the COF layer at this loading amount is around 8 μm, and thus the total thickness of COF-TzDha@PP is less than 33 μm (Fig. S5), which does not result in a great loss of energy density. In addition, the prepared COF-TzDha@PP separators have good flexibility (Inset in Fig. S5). The surfaces of PP and COF-TzDha@PP separators were investigated by SEM, and it can be found that the pores on the pristine PP separator were uniformly distributed, and the micrometre pores on the loaded PP separator were uniformly covered by the nano-bands of COF-TzDha (Fig. S6). The porosity of both the PP and COF-TzDha@PP separators was also analyzed by measuring their mass before and after immersion in n-butanol for 2 h. The calculated porosity of the commercial PP and COF@PP separators are 39.18% and 53.06%, respectively. Compared to the original PP, the porous framework and lithiophilic groups of COF-TzDha@PP significantly enhance its wettability with the electrolyte. To verify this inference, the wettability of pristine PP and COF-TzDha@PP with the electrolyte was investigated by measuring the electrolyte contact angle, and the results showed that the corresponding contact angles were 45° and 8°, respectively (Fig. 2f, g). In addition, Fig. 2h, i show the dynamic wetting process of the two different separators, where it can be seen that the modified separator was rapidly wetted after dropping the electrolyte, while the PP separator did not show any change. In general, better wettability reduces the cell resistance and increases the ionic conductivity, thereby achieving fast charge/discharge capability in LMBs. 3.2 Electrochemical performance of LMBs with COF-TzDha modified separators The electrochemical kinetic performance of the composite separator was explored by Tafel curves, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). The exchange current density (I 0) of the symmetric cells assembled with PP and COF-TzDha@PP, respectively, was obtained by testing Tafel. As shown in Fig. 3 a, the I 0 (0.56 mA cm−2) of the Li|COF-TzDha@PP|Li symmetric cell was higher than that of the Li|PP|Li symmetric cell (I 0 = 0.15 mA cm−2), indicating that the COF-modified separator contributes to the ion transport. To further investigate the effect of the COF-modified separator on the ion transport process, the activation energy (E 0) during the reaction was determined by the Arrhenius equation. As shown in Fig. 3b, the impedance value decreases as the ambient temperature increases (Fig. S7 and Table S2). The activation energies of the symmetric cells Li|PP|Li and Li|COF-TzDha@PP|Li were calculated to be 63.43 and 58.03 kJ mol−1, respectively. The significant decrease in the activation energy of the reaction confirms that the COF-modified separator contributes to the improvement of ionic conductivity, accelerates the de-embedding of lithium ions, and reduces the polarization of the cell during electrochemical cycling. In addition, the migration number ( t Li + ) of the symmetric battery was calculated at constant temperature according to the lithium ion migration number equation. The lithium ion migration number of Li|COF@PP|Li increased from 0.43 to 0.75 compared to the Li|PP|Li cell (Fig. 3c and Fig. S8). The change in migration number can be attributed to the fact that the two separators have different migration mechanisms. In Li|PP|Li cells, lithium ions generally migrate in the form of larger solvated clusters, so the lithium ions obtain a lower migration number [51]. In Li|COF@PP|Li cell, COF-TzDha can change the solvated structure of the lithium salt and the chemical environment of TFSI− due to the hydroxyl groups interacting electrostatically with the lithium ions and accelerating the migration of the lithium ions. When the solvent sheath passes through the pore, components with weaker interactions with lithium ions are anchored to the COF pore wall by hydrogen bonds. As a result, components with stronger interactions with lithium ions pass through the pores. This unique COF structure provides a lithium ion migration channel while lowering the migration energy barrier, resulting in a higher t Li + . In order to evaluate the effect of composite separators on the electrochemical performance of LMBs, Li symmetric batteries were tested by Galvanostatic charging/discharging. Battery stability under harsh conditions is a key factor. It is well known that the rapid transport of lithium ions at high current densities will exacerbate the generation of by-products, leading to increase the internal resistance of the battery and more pronounced polarization phenomenon. Therefore, we tested the two symmetric batteries at the current densities from 0.25 to 8 mA cm−2, respectively. The results show that the polarization voltages of Li|PP|Li and Li|COF@PP|Li cells are not significantly different at the lower current density of 0.25 mA cm−2, but the difference is gradually apparent with the increase of current density (Fig. 3d). At 1.0, 2.0, 4.0, and 8.0 mA cm−2, the polarization voltages of Li|PP|Li cells were 67.6, 144.8, 266, and 384.7 mV, respectively, whereas Li|COF@PP|Li cells exhibited lower polarisations with voltages of 28.8, 53, 88.4, and 111.6 mV, respectively, which suggests that the composite separator plays a significant role in inducing the uniform lithium deposition and Li+ flux (Fig. 3e). The cycling stability of Li|PP|Li and Li|COF@PP|Li symmetric cells is illustrated in Fig. 3f. At a current density of 1.0 mA cm−2 and a fixed capacity of 1.0 mA h cm−2, the potential of the unmodified Li|PP|Li cell increased dramatically after 100 h of cycling, indicating that lithium metal produced a significant number of dendrites during long-term cycling, and the accumulation of dendrites eventually punctured the separator and led to short circuit in the battery. The Li|COF@PP|Li symmetric cell demonstrated impressive cycling stability, exceeding 1000 h, with and a low polarization voltage (15 mV) due to the large number of active sites on COF-TzDha. When the current was increased to 4 mA cm−2, Li|PP|Li and Li|COF@PP|Li cells exhibited polarization voltages of 0.09 and 0.11–0.45 V over 1200 and 200 h, respectively (Fig. 3g). Such low over-potential, combined with large current density and deposition capacity surpass those symmetrical cells with other COFs modified separators (Tables S3 and S4). The lower polarization voltage and the ultra-long cycle life indicate that the COF-TzDha modified separator can effectively inhibit the growth of dendrites. The effect of the modified separator on the anode was further investigated by electrochemical impedance testing. Previously reported work verified that the formation of dendrites and the accumulation of by-products increase the cell impedance, the size of the high-frequency semicircle diameters in the Nyquist plot and serve as a measure of the dendrites/by-products formation, which is critical to the electrochemical performance [52]. As shown in Fig. S9, for the Li|PP|Li symmetric cell, the cell impedance increased from 192 to 331 Ω after 200 cycles, which indicates that the unmodified separator produced a large number of dendrites and “dead lithium” during the long cycling process, leading to an increase in impedance. In contrast, the impedance of Li|COF@PP|Li symmetric cell decreased slightly after 200 cycles. The results indicate that the COF-TzDha@PP separator induces uniform deposition/stripping of lithium ions, thereby slowing down the occurrence of side reactions and effectively suppressing dendrite growth. In particular, the electron-rich triazine ring attracts lithium ions, and solvent molecules are effectively anchored after forming hydrogen bonds with hydrooxyl groups. To further verify the synergistic effects of the two mechanisms, we synthesized two control COFs: one with only a triazine structure (COF-TzPA) and the other with a polar hydroxyl group (COF-TAPB-Dha), as shown in Schemes S1 and S2. The electrochemical performance of Li-Li symmetric cells with COF-TzPA and COF-TAPB-Dha modified separators is shown in Fig. S10. The COF-modified separators effectively reduced polarization and improved stability compared to commercial PP separators. COF-TAPB-Dha@PP remained stable after 400 h of cycling with an overpotential of 30 mV, while COF-TzPA@PP showed a sharp increase in overpotential after 400 h, indicating dendrite formation and potential short circuiting. In contrast, COF-TzDha@PP demonstrated excellent cycling stability (>1000 h) with a low overpotential (15 mV). These results highlight the importance of introducing triazine-based structures and hydroxyl groups for uniform Li-ion deposition, preventing dendrite formation in LMB. Additionally, SEM, XRD, and FTIR analyses were used to confirm structural changes in the cycled COF-TzDha@PP separator (Fig. S11). These analyses show good electrochemical and structural stability of the separator. Notably, the FTIR spectrum displayed a strong CO bond stretching vibration at 1066 cm−1. This peak shifted to a lower wavenumber after cycling, indicating hydrogen bonding between the COH group and the oxygen and fluorine atoms in DOL, DME, and TFSI−, which increased the electron density of CO [53]. This confirms the role of polar hydroxyl groups in modifying the lithium ion solvation structure. 3.3 Surface structure and component analysis of LMA with COF-TzDha modified separators after cycling The microstructure of the electrode after cycling further confirms the protective effect of the composite separators on lithium metal. After long-term electroplating/stripping of the battery assembled with commercial PP separators, a large number of two-dimensional mossy lithium dendrites were observed on the lithium foil surface ( Fig. 4 a). It was found through side view that lithium metal deposition was uneven after cycling, resulting in the formation of a porous and fluffy structure (Fig. S12a). In addition, numerous irregular holes were observed on the Cu electrode, which may be related to the generation of “dead lithium”. As the lithium dendrites continued to grow, lithium ions were heavily deposited on the surface of the lithium foil, forming a thick SEI film. Meanwhile, reactions between fresh lithium metal and the liquid electrolyte, continuously consuming the electrolyte and leading to the generation of “dead lithium” and irreversible loss of lithium metal (Fig. 4b, c). This process resulted in numerous defects on the surface of the lithium foil, where lithium ions tended to accumulate, causing rapid deposition of a large number of lithium ions and exacerbating the instability of the lithium electroplating/stripping process. In contrast, the lithium foil in the COF-TzDha@PP membrane battery exhibited a smooth surface (Fig. 4d), indicating that the introduction of COF can effectively induce uniform deposition of lithium ions. This result is also supported by the side view (Fig. S12b). The deposition layer on the Cu electrode mainly exhibited a columnar structure, with close contact between columns and almost no dendrite formation (Fig. 4e, f). The thickness of the deposited layer at this current density and deposition capacity were also assessed, as illustrated in Fig. S13, the thickness of the deposited layer is approximately 37 μm. The difference in thickness may be due to the loss of active lithium associated with the PP separators. Additionally, we discuss the deposition effects of Li-Cu half-cells with PP and COF-TzDha@PP separators at different capacities (Fig. S14). The Cu electrode protected by the COF-TzDha@PP separator at a deposition capacity of 1 mA h cm−2 obtains a smooth surface, while the unprotected Cu electrode formed a large number of holes and generates “dead lithium”. Ultimately, when the deposition capacity is increased to 10 mA h cm−2, the unprotected Cu electrode becomes entirely covered with “dead lithium”. To further analyze the elemental composition on the electrode surface, XPS testing was conducted on the lithium metal by disassembling the battery after cycling. In the C 1s spectrum, peaks at 284.8, 287, 290, and 293.1 eV correspond to CC, CO, CO, and CF bonds, while peaks at 285.4 and 289 eV represent CN and CN bonds in COF-TzDha (Fig. 4g, j). In the F 1s spectrum (Fig. 4h, k), peaks at 689 and 685.22 eV correspond to CF and LiF. Lastly, the Li 1s spectrum (Fig. 4i, l) displays peaks at 54.7, 55.35, and 55.7 eV, representing ROCO2Li, Li2CO3, and LiF. Compared to the PP separator, the introduction of COF-TzDha leads to a significant increase in the LiF component. It is well known that LiF is an excellent ionic conductor and can induce effective nucleation of Li ions during the reduction process. In addition, LiF can passivate the electrode surface and avoid the generation of side reactions. Therefore, the triazine-based COF promotes the formation of LiF-rich SEI layer, which contributes to the improvement of the electrochemical performance of LMBs. 3.4 Electrochemical performance of Li|COF@PP|Cu half cell and Li|COF@PP|LFP full cells CE is a crucial metric for evaluating the reversibility of LMBs, and the assembly of half cells with a COF-TzDha interlayer for galvanostatic discharge/charge test to evaluate the utilization of lithium metal during the plating and stripping process. As shown in Fig. 5 a, b, at a current density of 1.0 mA cm−2, the over-potentials of the Li|PP|Cu half-cells at the 50th and 100th cycles were 50 and 54 mV, respectively, and the overpotentials exhibited a tendency of decreasing and then increasing, which was attributed to the occurrence of the side reactions during the cycling process that led to the consumption of part of the active lithium and the deposition process of the “dead lithium” formation, leading to active lithium bare accelerate the continued growth of dendrites. On the other hand, the Li|COF-PP|Cu half cell maintains a relatively stable thermal energy after 100 cycles of stripping/deposition, decreasing from 35.4 to 30.4 mV at the beginning, which indicates that the modified separator can effectively induce uniform deposition of lithium ions, and abundant nucleation sites can slow down the growth of the dendrites and the generation of “dead lithium”. This indicates that the modified separator can effectively induce uniform deposition of lithium ions, and the abundance of nucleation sites can slow down the growth of dendrites and “dead lithium”. Fig. 5c shows the CE behaviors of the two types of separators at a current density of 1.0 mA cm−2 and a capacity of 1.0 mA h cm−2. The CE of the Li|PP|Cu half-cells decreases drastically after 120 cycles, which can be attributed to the large number of dendrites growth and the accumulation of “dead lithium”. This can be attributed to the large amount of dendrite growth and the accumulation of “dead lithium”. Conversely, the Li|COF-PP|Cu half-cell can still maintain a Coulombic efficiency of 98.48% after 240 cycles, which suggests that the introduction of COF-TzDha can induce a more homogeneous deposition/dissolution of lithium ions, which effectively avoids the generation of “dead lithium” and the growth of dendrites, and thus prolongs the cycling life of the cell. In order to evaluate the feasibility of composite separators for practical applications, we assembled a full cell using LiFePO4 (LFP) as the cathode. Fig. 5d shows the cyclic voltammetry curves for the first three cycles, with a pair of typical redox peaks reflecting the extraction and insertion of lithium in the voltage range of 2.0–4.2 V and a sweep rate of 0.1 mV s−1. The cathode/anode peaks remained unchanged over three cycles, confirming the full-cell stability of the COF-TzDha@PP separator. As shown in Fig. 5e, the full cell specific discharge capacities with the COF-TzDha@PP separator were 147, 133, 126, 120, 110, and 91 mA h g−1 at 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, 4.0, 5.0, and 8.0 C, respectively, while the specific discharge capacities of the full cell with PP separator were reduced to 130, 123, 117, 108, 90, and 66 mA h g−1. It is noteworthy that the full-cell discharge capacity with the COF-TzDha@PP separator still maintained a high capacity of 139 mA h g−1 when the current density was restored to 0.5 mA h g−1, demonstrating its stability and reversibility. As shown in Fig. 5f, the capacity-voltage curves at 1.0 C indicate that the full cell with the COF-TzDha@PP separator displays a smaller polarization voltage (0.2 V) than that of the pure PP separator (0.28 V) (Fig. S15), and the stable discharge/charge plateau demonstrates a more moderate reaction process. As shown in Fig. 5g, the long-term cycling performance of the full cell with the COF-TzDha@PP separator at 1.0 C shows remarkable stability, with a relatively small capacity degradation (75% capacity retention) and a Coulombic efficiency close to 100% after 600 cycles. In contrast, the capacity of the full cell with the PP separator decreased sharply after 300 cycles due to the large loss of active lithium and the accumulation of “dead lithium”. The retention rate was less than 50% after 326 cycles, and the Coulombic efficiency gradually decayed to <89%. The electrochemical state of the full cell with the COF-TzDha@PP separator under different cycle times was investigated by impedance diagrams, revealing that the charge transfer resistance (R ct) decreased with the increase in cycle times (Fig. S16). This finding indicates that the COF-TzDha@PP separator possesses excellent lithium ion migration ability and can effectively avoid the formation of dendrites. In addition, a pouch cell assembled from COF-TzDha@PP with a 30 μm Li/Cu anode and LFP cathode (3.0 mg cm−2) can easily drive a 3 V handheld fan with a micro-DC motor for more than 3 min, verifying its promising practical application (Fig. 5h and Supplementary Video S1). To confirm the practical application of COF-TzDha@PP, a full cell with high areal loading of LFP (∼8 mg cm2) was tested. As shown in Fig. S17, the Li-LFP full cell with modified separators maintained 85.4% capacity retention after 400cycles at 1.0 C, while the commercial PP separator showed rapid degradation with only 66.2% retention after 300 cycles. Similarly, the Li-LFP pouch cell with high areal loading (∼8 mg cm2) demonstrated good cycle stability at 0.5 C (Fig. S18), further supporting the potential of COF-TzDha@PP for practical applications. 3.5 DFT theoretical calculation for the binding energies between COF-TzDha and solvent molecules To further illustrate the interaction between COF-TzDha and solvent molecules, the charge density of COF was calculated using first-principle DFT. As shown in Fig. 6 a, DFT calculation results reveal three different active sites on COF. In addition, the binding energies between Li+ and each of the active sites, solvents, and anions on COF were also calculated (Fig. 6b–g). The results indicate that the magnitude of the binding energies of each substance with Li+ follows the order of TFSI− > COF-N1 > COF-N2 > COF-O > COF-DME > COF-DOL. The binding energies of adsorption sites for N1, N2, and O in COF with lithium ions were −2.982, −2.839, and −2.332 eV, respectively. Although the binding energies of lithium ions with the anion TFSI− were as high as up to −5.873, it may not be the main state of Li+ because it is diluted in the solvent. The binding energies between DOL and DME in the solvent and lithium ion are both lower than the individual active sites on COF, suggesting that the COF material will compete with the solvent molecules for the lithium ion. In addition, the ionic diffusion kinetics of the electrolyte was evaluated by molecular dynamics (MD) modelling. The electrolyte diffusion model was constructed by adding LiTFSI into the channels of COF-TzDha (Fig. 6h). After 1000 ps, lithium ions were uniformly distributed in the channel, which was attributed to the adsorption of lithium ions by the regular active sites on COF-TzDha. Due to the large number of hydroxyl functional groups on COF-TzDha, a large amount of TFSI− was anchored near the channel mouth after the formation of hydrogen bonds with anions (Fig. 6i). Calculations showed that the Li+ diffusion coefficient was 2.377 × 10−3 A2 ps−1 and the TFSI− diffusion coefficient was 4.682 × 10−4 A2 ps−1 in COF-TzDha (Fig. 6j). Therefore, the de-solvation of lithium ions is finally achieved through the adsorption of lithium ions on the active sites and the anchoring of hydroxyl groups to the solvent molecules [54]. These conclusions are in agreement with the experimental results. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have introduced a polar-rich group triazine-based COF with a desolvation effect as a multifunctional inter-layer to induce uniform Li ion flux and deposition for dendrite-free, stable LMBs. Experimental and calculative results indicate that the abundant triazine structures and ordered channels on COF-TzDha facilitate lithium ion migration, ensuring a uniform lithium ion flux. Additionally, the polar groups (OH) form hydrogen bonds (OHO) with dilute electrolyte components, anchoring solvent sheath molecules and impeding their migration. This effectively promotes the rapid dissociation of lithium ions. At 4 mA cm−2/4.0 mA h cm−2, the Li|COF@PP|Li symmetric cell achieves long stable cycling for more than 1200 h with a low overpotential. Additionally, the Li|COF@PP|LFP full cell also demonstrates superior cycling stability with 600 cycles at 1 C. Therefore, this work verifies an effective strategy to induce the uniform Li+ flux and deposition for dendrite-free LMA through using a polar-rich-group COF with a desolvation effect as an inter-layer. coredata.dc:description: The uneven deposition and high reactivity of lithium-metal anode (LMA) lead to uncontrollable dendrite growth, low Coulombic efficiency, and safety concerns, hindering their commercialization. Here, a representative polar-rich-group triazine-based covalent organic framework (COF-TzDha) with a desolvation effect is designed as an interlayer for stable, dendrite-free LMA. The abundant triazine rings in COF-TzDha as a donor effectively attract lithium ions, while the one-dimensional nanopore structure facilitates lithium-ion migration. The periodic arrangement of polar groups (–OH) in the backbone interacts with electrolyte components (DOL, DME, TFSI−) to form a hydrogen bonding network that slows solvent molecules transport. Therefore, COF-TzDha effectively desolvates lithium ions from the solvent sheath, promoting uniform lithium ion flux and Li plating/stripping. Theoretical calculations verify that COF-TzDha with abundant adsorption sites and strong adsorption energy facilitates lithium ion de-solvation. Consequently, the introduction of COF-TzDha obtains a high ion mobility (0.75). The Li|COF@PP|Li symmetric cell cycles stably for over 1200 h at 4 mA cm−2/4.0 mA h cm−2. The Li|COF@PP|LiFePO4 full cell also displays highly stable cycling performance with 600 cycles (75.5% capacity retention, ∼100% Coulombic efficiency) at 1 C. This work verifies an effective strategy for inducing uniform Li deposition and achieving dendrite-free, stable LMA using a polar-rich-group COF interlayer with a desolvation effect.
